channel.title: The FT Money show
channel.itunes:author: FT.com
channel.description: The FT Money show: your weekly guide to personal finance
channel.itunes:subtitle: The FT Money show: your weekly guide to personal finance
channel.itunes:summary: The FT Money show: your weekly guide to personal finance
channel.copyright: Copyright The Financial Times Ltd 2007. 'FT' and 'Financial Times' are trademarks of the Financial Times.

item.title: FT Money Show, 13 November 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: Why there are now opportunities to cut your inheritance bill? After the interest rate cut, can you still get a cheap tracker-rate mortgage? Plus, some good news amid the bad news about investing in funds.

item.title: FT Money Show, 6 November 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: Will the base rate cut really be good news for borrowers? Plus, will Barack Obama's election lift the US equities markets, and a credit card that offers you 3 per cent cashback in the run up to Christmas

item.title: FT Money Show, 30 October 2008
item.author: support@ft.com

item.title: FT Money Show, 23 October 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: Frozen in Iceland: what are the chances of getting your offshore savings back? A guide to alternatives to annuities And mixed news on hedge funds and small-cap shares

item.title: FT Money Show, 16 October 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: As the dust settles, how the UK bank bail-out affects you How to get a mortgage from the private banks And is it time to buy US shares?

item.title: FT Money Show, 9 October 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: What the bank rescue package means for savings, mortgages and investments Are investors reacting rationally to the storm? And some thoughts on the defensive sectors where investors can take shelter

item.title: FT Money show, 2 October 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: With confidence in banks so low that they won't lend to each other, what hope do borrowers in the UK have of getting an affordable mortgage? Is this the end of the line for buy-to-let morgages? Plus: How badly have pension funds been hit by falling equity markets and what should investors do?

item.title: FT Money show, 25 September 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: Where can investors find safety in the financial storm? Mortgage rates rise again - and it's not just first time buyers being priced out of the market. Plus: good news and bad news on tax free savings

item.title: Money Show 18 September
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: A special edition of the money show, focusing on the effects of the financial crisis on savers, mortgage-holders and shareholders. Plus - how pensions for eight year-olds could set them up for life.

item.title: Money Show 11 September 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: Have UK shares bounced off the bottom? How to profit from the plunging pound And some good news for mortgage borrowers

item.title: Money Show 4 September 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: With house price indices diverging, which is the most reliable? Plus - one analyst calls the end of the equities bear market, and how to safeguard your inheritance

item.title: Money Show 28 August 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: Did you know that if your bank loses your data, you might be entitled to compensation just for the stress? Plus part-exchanging properties and investing in Latin America

item.title: Money Show 21 August 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: Should you transfer your 'contracted out' pension fund? Why some City workers can't buy unemployment cover And how to inflation-proof your savings

item.title: Money Show 14 August 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: Should investors start reinvesting in the US? Fraud abroad: how your card may be holidaying without you And the good and bad news about falling mortgage rates

item.title: Money Show 7 August 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: Could stamp duty concessions kickstart the housing market? A guide to the worst performing funds, with advice on safeguarding your investments. And how a smart postcode might affect your pension.

item.title: Money Show 31 July 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: Summer is heating up savings rates again Putting a Thai hotel room in a self-invested pension And the bad and good news on the 35% price hike by British Gas

item.title: Money Show 24 July 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: Has the housing market hit rock bottom? Are luxury goods firms being squeezed like the rest of us? And good and bad news about a scheme for donating small lots of shares to charity

item.title: Money Show 18 July 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: The winners and losers from the Santander bid for Alliance and Leicester Is it time to invest in Japan? And how to keep your cash ahead of inflation

item.title: Money Show 11 July 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: As expected the Bank of England has held base rates at 5%, so why are mortgage rates still moving all over the place? Inflation-proofing your pension: what rising prices today mean for your retirement income Paying your tax on time: you only have a few days left if you are self employed or a buy-to-let landlord And some good news and bad news on a home loan under 5%

item.title: Money Show 4 July 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: The rights and wrongs of bank's share issues: should you part with more cash? Insurance against higher mortgage rates - a new product that protects borrowers on variable rates Pensions: why anyone who contracted out of the second state pension can give their self-invested pension a big boost And we have some good news and bad news on foreign exchange deals

item.title: Money Show 27 June 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description:
Housing market - with mortgage rates rising out of step with base rates, can it still be cheaper to buy than rent?
Investment funds - have any fund managers been able to keep their heads - and your money - above water in volatile markets?
Spanish property - why Brits owning abroad may be due tax rebate of nearly 20,000GBP
Plus: good news and Bad News on long-term savings

item.title: FT Money show, 20 June 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: This week: Savings rates of 7 per cent - but is it any good if inflation is rising? Investing in India - still a good idea? How a postcode lottery is shaking up the pensions market; plus building society mergers.

item.title: FT Money show, 13 June 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: Inflation - how much of a threat is it to fund investors, and what are fund managers doing about it? Stock-market indicators - why American consumers, truck drivers, and Disneyland holidaymakers have good news for UK shareholders Tax-efficient investments - how to take and old 40 per cent capital tax gains bill and shrink it to 18 per cent Plus: good news and bad news on the high-street savings accounts

item.title: FT Money show, 6 June 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: Bradford & Bingley - is the buy-to-let lender an investment in ruins or an investment opportunity? Mortgage rates - why the best deals are to be found not on the high street but in the oak-panelled halls of the private banks; why a so-called variable annuity can actually give you more certainty in retirement; and good and bad news on managing your credit card bills.

item.title: FT Money show, 30 May 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: Happy Tax Freedom Day - the day we stop working for the government and start for ourselves - but could it be earlier in the year? Coping with redundancy; Driven to drink - how to trade wine futures; and good news and bad news on savings rates.

item.title: FT Money show, 23 May 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: unfair bank charges - will compensation ever come? Emerging markets: is it easier or safer to invest in them through UK blue chips? Volatile markets - why it's better to be in than out; and good news and bad news on cash-backs that cut the cost of travel

item.title: FT Money show, 16 May 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: inflation is up but income tax is down - what do this week's announcements mean for borrowers and savers; House prices aren't all falling - we look at areas on the up; Pension investors - the unlikely winners in the credit crunch? And good news and bad news on making payments in euros.

item.title: FT Money show, 9 May 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: Why borrowers are struggling to find standard variable rate mortgages with no fee; a positive return every month and 10% a year - Nicola Horlick on a fund manager's secrets; how to avoid 40% inheritance tax; and some good news and bad news on regular saving.

item.title: FT Money show, 2 May 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: Why aren't savings rates going down? How to be a private currency trader; Asian equity markets - are they a good diversification strategy? Plus good news and bad news on Peps and Isas.

item.title: FT Money show, 25 April 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: This week: 50 billion from the Bank of England, but will it make any difference to mortgages? Putting property into your pension - is it still a good idea? Why we are so bad at making decisions, and what we can do about it - a behavioural psychologist explains. Plus the good news and bad news on using credit cards abroad.

item.title: FT Money show, 18 April 2008 - Mortgage special
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: long-term fixed rates - will government action make them cheaper? Buy-to-let mortgages - are they still a good idea as house prices fall? European property - can you hedge against costly euro mortgages?

item.title: FT Money show, 11 April 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: Mortgages - who benefits from the rate cut? Water - is it really 'blue gold' for investors? Commercial property - legal threats over fund lock-ins

item.title: FT Money show, 4 April 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: housing market - how the mortgage squeeze is cutting asking prices; Agricultural commodities - what's the best way to invest as prices fall? Emerging markets - why New Star is launching a new India fund

item.title: FT Money show, 28 March 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: UK mortgage upheaval - are people looking for alternative property investments abroad? The good news and bad news on equity ISAs. Plus, a long view of the markets.

item.title: FT Money show, 21 March 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: Bank shares or bank account - should you take the risk, or take 6 per cent? Executive pensions - how to switch plans and keep benefits? Emerging markets funds - can they keep on growing?

item.title: FT Money show 14 March 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's Budget 2008 special: Enterprise investment schemes - why they're even more tax efficient? Stamp duty and mortgages - where was the help for homebuyers? 'Sin' taxes on tobacco and alcohol - how it helps with life insurance?

item.title: FT Money show, 7 March 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: Income investments - which are most tax-efficient in an Isa? Free financial advice - what will the new government proposals offer? Inflation-proof savings - why an RPI-linked Isa is a market-beater

item.title: FT Money show, 29 February 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: No description

item.title: FT Money show, 22 February 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: Guaranteed savings: why Northern Rock is safer than foreign banks; Tax-efficient investments - what Enterprise Investment Schemes offer; Star fund managers - who performs the best in volatile markets

item.title: FT Money show, 15 February 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: This week: tax rules and U-turns - the latest on tax planning for investors in individual savings accounts (Isas), and for non-doms with offshore trusts; commodities - how to profit from falling oil, gold and crop prices; and overseas banks - where to find savings rates of 6.5 per cent

item.title: FT Money show, 8 February 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: This week: Another interest-rate cut - why it's not all bad news for savers, or good news for all borrowers; Investment funds - how to profit from shipping, food and pop music; and green investments - what are the prospects for clean energy?

item.title: FT Money show, 1 February 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: Savings rates - guess who is offering 6.99 per cent with instant access? Buy-to-let property - can rising yields offset slow price growth? And pension investments - do volatile markets put retirement at risk?

item.title: FT Money show, 25 January 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: Market falls and recession fears: how they affect your finances; Exchange-traded tracker funds: is now the time to invest? Tax planning: what the new rules mean for offshore trusts.

item.title: FT Money show, 18 January 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: Commercial property - the professional vultures are swooping on cheap assets but what should private investors do? Is it too late to join the gold rush? Tips on making self assessment less painful; The good and bad news of 0 per cent credit cards.

item.title: FT Money show, 11 January 2008
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: savings and loan deals: the best of the bank 'sales'; shares and currencies: the effects of a weaker pound; venture capital: the changes to the risks and rewards.

item.title: FT Money show, 21 December 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: market predictions for 2008: forecasts for shares and house prices; commercial property funds - discounts and buying opportunities; plus smarter ways to switch gas and electricity suppliers

item.title: FT Money show, 14 December 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: Markets outlook: is the rally over, and what will 2008 bring? Savings rates: how to get 8 per cent, even as rates fall; Mortgage insurance: a new scheme to protect homeowners

item.title: FT Money show, 7 December 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: Cash deposits: should you move into cash, in spite of the rate cut? Actively-managed funds: are they a better bet than 'quant' funds? Wealth secrets: how to learn them through social networking

item.title: FT Money show, 30 November 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: insuring against falling house prices: what homeowners can do now; Getting out of commercial property: should fund investors sell up? Plus: investing in a Sipp: is a 'full' pension or a low-cost plan better?

item.title: FT Money Show 23 November 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: Residential property: why buyers are resorting to 'gazundering' again. Tax-efficient investments: which is better - a pension or an Isa? Lower-cost funds: how investors benefit from a GBP300m VAT rebate.

item.title: FT Money Show 16 November 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: The credit crunch hits Christmas: why card issuers are behaving like Ebenezer Scrooge with their credit limits. The gold rush: forget the yellow stuff - platinum is exciting some investors right now. The end of private equity? Is a lack of cheap borrowing facilities limiting the opportunities for private investors? Plus good news and bad news for cash-back deals.

item.title: FT Money show, 9 November 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: Bank shares: should investors sell or hold, as the credit crisis rolls on? Exchange traded funds: how new funds do more than track an index. Emerging markets: Dr Mark Mobius goes in search of small caps

item.title: FT Money show, 2 November 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: Will the chancellor do a U-turn on capital gains tax changes? Should private investors buy into agricultural commodities? Is buy-to-let still a good investment as the housing market slows?

item.title: FT Money show. 26 Oct 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: This week: pension planning: How a flexible annuity can deliver a higher income; inheritance tax: What to leave to your children - and how; Sharedealing and spread-betting: How the European 'Mifid' regulations will affect you, when they come into force in November

item.title: FT Money Show, 19 Oct 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: This week: is it time to get out of commercial property, as property prices and fund values fall? will the regulatory shake-up of financial advice give you a better deal? and some good and bad news on mortgage rates.

item.title: FT Money Show, 12 Oct 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: This week: Pre-budget report special - what chancellor Darling's changes to inheritance tax and capital gains tax will mean for you.

item.title: FT Money Show, 5 Oct 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: This week: ethical funds - how to check if you might be invested in Burma; mixed news on cashback cards; and a guide to timing investments in collective funds.

item.title: FT Money Show, 28 September 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: This week: should you rely on private medical insurance or NHS provision? mixed news on credit cards; and the pros and cons of split capital invesment trusts.

item.title: FT Money Show, 21 September 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: This week: a guide to low-cost trackers in uncertain markets; planning tips for your tax return; and mixed news for First Direct customers.

item.title: FT Money show, 14 September 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: the best use of cash when savings rates top 7 per cent; How your postcode can affect your pension income. Plus where to find car insurance quotes you can trust

item.title: FT Money show, 7 September 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: why banks are taking a closer look at who they are lending to; new ways to profit from oil prices, as shares remain volatile; plus how writing a will can save you tax - and benefit your pet

item.title: FT Money show, 31 August 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: This week: what???s the best place to invest a child trust fund? How parents and investors can buy into student property, plus why late payment of tax bills is now even more costly

item.title: FT Money show, 24 August 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: This week: is releasing equity from your home really a good idea? The latest developments on the expansion of home information packs; How new regulations will affect smaller financial advisers

item.title: FT Money Show, 17 Aug 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: This week:tips on how to make and save money; which way mortgage rates are heading; and how you can pass on assets to future generations without passing on exorbitant tax and good news - bad news.

item.title: FT Money Show, 10 Aug 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: This week: is this really the end of mortgage exit fees? how paying on a card abroad can cost you dear; the rise in insurance premiums after the recent floods; and will investment boards stick to their pledges to buy back shares?

item.title: FT Money show, 3 August 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: Do hedge funds really protect against market volatility? Why the OFT is taking banks to court over charges; and is now the time to snap up a place in the sun?

item.title: FT Money show, 27 July 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: Is the UK's love affair with commercial property over? Do widening investment trust discounts signal a buying opportunity? plus save tax and ease your conscience with charitable giving

item.title: FT Money show, 20 July 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: This week the Money Show clears up the confusion about self-invested personal pensions or SIPPS; examines the pros and cons of 25-year mortgages; asks if consumers should be investing in pharmaceutical stocks; and looks at the impact of the strong pound on investing in the US.

item.title: FT Money show, 13 July 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: This week: How green is your wallet? We look at the eco credentials of bank accounts and credit cards; and the price of property funds.

item.title: FT Money show, 6 July 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: This week: how to protect your property against flood damage. Is the bottom falling out of the buy-to-let market? Plus divorce at the supermarket - is there anything that Tescos won't sell?

item.title: FT Money show, 29 June 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: This week: how to get a piece of the private equity action. The Chinese bubble - what would a stock market correction mean for emerging market funds? Plus the latest money news, including the pros and cons of switching current accounts.

item.title: FT Money show, 22 June 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: Matthew Vincent, editor of Investors Chronicle, presents the long and short of long-short funds. Can investing in climate change make a difference to the planet and your pocket? And how giving up smoking can cut the cost of your insurance.

item.title: FT Money show, 15 June 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: Robert Budden, the FT's personal finance editor, and Matthew Vincent, edior of Investors Chronicle on whether bonds now are a good buy; Do 100 per cent mortgages make sense; The Zopa lending model unravelled.

item.title: FT Money show, 8 June 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: This week: Protecting your home for less, looking after your profits plus advice on how to insure your art collection.

item.title: FT Money show, 1 June 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: This week: Cheaper mobile calls from abroad, lower-cost pensions, and shareholder perks

item.title: FT Money show, 25 May 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: With mortgage rates rising, are buy-to-let properties still a good investment? How green is your car insurance? A look at carbon neutral cover. Plus commission rates and your pension: advice on income drawdown.

item.title: FT Money show, 18 May 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's show: how to get more bang from your holiday buck; are interest rate hikes hurting the property market? And, 10 years on, should you hold onto shares in former building societies?

item.title: FT Money show, 11 May 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: This week: when interest rates rise why do savings rates lag so far behind? How much should your investment in ISAs have grown? And are the yields from bond funds and commercial property funds still attractive?

item.title: FT Money show, 04 May 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: This week: the true cost of estate agents' free home information packs; Should you switch energy supplier? Why stockbrokers are turning to spread betting. Plus split capital investment trusts demystified.

item.title: FT Money show, 27 April 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In this week's FT Money programme: Does selling in May pay dividends? How to cut your tax bill on the sale of a holiday home. Should you fix your mortgage? Plus more on the rights of nominee shareholders.

item.title: FT Money show, 20 April 2007
item.author: support@ft.com
item.description: In the first FT Money programme: why rattling windows, amongst other things, could cost you money; one of the UK's most successful fund managers launches a new product - at the age of 78; and listeners and readers questions on building society windfalls.
